justification: The article states that "The BIS-BAS scale (Carver & White, 1994) was administered after completing the four conditions," indicating this questionnaire was used to measure BIS and BAS sensitivities.

Participants played a two-response Matching Pennies game and the researchers calculated "item-based shift rate" to analyse win-stay and lose-shift patterns, showing the task served as the behavioural measure of these constructs.
The study used a 120-trial three-response RPS game and analysed post-win and post-loss shift rates, demonstrating the RPS task was employed to measure win-stay/lose-shift behaviour.
In the five-response "Elemental" game the authors recorded item-based shift rates to examine win-stay and lose-shift tendencies, using the game as the measurement instrument.

measured_by: Dice Dual task (6-response odd/even dice game)
justification: The novel six-response "Dice Dual" game was used to track between- and within-category shifts, allowing the authors to quantify win-stay/lose-shift behaviour and outcome-independent random exploration.
